editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Maydes tragedy.
titleStmt.author: Beaumont, Francis, 1584-1616.
Fletcher, John, 1579-1625.

div.p: As it hath been divers times acted at the Blackfriars by the King's majesty's servants.
London printed for Richard Higgenbotham and are to be sold at the angel in Paul's churchyard. 1619.

list.item: Callianax an old humorous lord, and father to Aspasia.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: The rest are making ready sir,

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: So let them, there's time enough.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: You are brother to the King my lord, we'll take your word.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Strato thou hast some skill in poetry,
What think'st thou of a mask, will it be well?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: As well as masks can be.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Yes, they must commend, and speak in praise of the assembly, bless the bride and groom, in person of some god, there tied to rules of flattery.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See good my lord who is returned.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Noble Melantius,Enter Melantiusthe land by me welcomes thy virtues home, thou that with blows abroad bringst us our peace at home, the breath of Kings is like the breath of gods, my brother wished thee here, and thou art here, he will be kind; and weary thee with often welcome, but the time doth give thee a welcome, above his, or all the world.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
My lord, my thanks, but these scratched limbs of mine, have spoke my love and truth unto my friends, more than my tongue ere could, my mind's the same it ever
was to you; where I find worth
sp.l: I love the keeper, till he let it go,
And then I follow it.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: Haile worthy brother,
He that rejoices not at your return
In safety, is mine enemy for ever.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I thank thee Diphilus: but thou art faulty,
I sent for thee to exercise thine arms
With me at patria, thou camest not Diphilus:
'Twas ill.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: My noble brother my excuse
Is my King's straight command, which you my lord
Can witness with me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis most true Melantius,
He might not come till the solemnities
Of this great match were passed.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yes, and have given cause to those, that here
Envy my deeds abroad, to call me gamesome,
I have no other business here at Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: We have a mask tonight ,
And you must tread a soldier's measure.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: These soft and silken wars are not for me,
The music must be shrill and all confused
That stirs my blood, and then I dance,
But is Amintor wed?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: All joys upon him, for he is my friend,
Wonder not that I call a man so young;
His worth is great, valiant he is,
And one that never thinks his life his own,
If his friend need it, when he was a boy,
As oft as I returned (As without boast)
I brought home conquest, he would gaze upon me,
And view me round, to found in what one limb
The virtue lay to do those things he heard,
Then would he wish to see my sword, and feel
the quickness of the edge, and in his hand
Weighs it, he oft would make me smile at this;
His youth did promise much, and his ripe years
Will see it all performed. Enter Aspatia passing with attendance.
Haile maid and wife.
Thou fair Aspasia, may the holy knot,
That thou hast tied today, last till the hand
Of age undo't, mayst thou bring a race
Unto Amintor, that may fill the world
Successively with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: My hard fortunes
Deserve not scorn, for I was never proud
When they were good. Exit Aspatia.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You are mistaken sir, she is not married.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon me, I did receive
Letters at patria from my Amintor
That he should marry her.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: And so it stood,
In all opinion long, but your arrival
Made me imagine you had heard the change.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: A lady sir,
That bears the light above her, and strikes dead
With flashes of her eye, the fair Euadne
Your virtuous sister.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Peace of heart betwixt them,
But this is strange.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The King my brother did it
To honour you, and these solemnities
Are at his charge.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis royal like himself,
But I am sad, my speech bears so infortunate a sound
To beautiful Aspasia, there is rage
Hid in her father's breast Calianax,
bent long against me and 'a should not think,
Could I but call it back, that I would take
Such base revenges as to scorn the state
Of his neglected daughter.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: O 'twere pity, for this lady sir,
Sits discontented with her watery eyes bent on the ear
In unfrequented woods are her delight,
Where when she sees a bank stuck full of flowers,
Than she will sit, and sigh, and tell
Her servants, what a pretty place it were
To bury lovers in, and make her maids
Pluck 'em, and strew them over her like a corpse,
She carries with her an infectious grief,
That strikes all her beholders, she will sing
The mournfulst things that ever ear hath heard,
And swoon, and sing again, and when the rest
Of your young ladies in their wanton blood,
Tell mirthful tales in course that fills the room
With laughter, she will with so sad a look
Bring forth a story of the silent death
Of some forsaken virgin, which her grief
Will put in such a phrase, that ere she end
She'll send them weeping one by one away.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: She has a brother under my command
Like her, a face as womanish as hers,
But with a spirit that hath much outgrown
The number of his years. Enter Amintor.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I might run fiercely, not more hastily,
Upon my foe, I love thee well Amintor,
My mouth is much too narrow for my heart,
I joy to look upon those eyes of thine,
Thou art my friend, but my disordred speech
Cuts off my love.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Thou art Melantius,
All love is spoke in that, a sacrifice
To thank the gods, Melantius is returned
in safety, victory sits on his sword
As she was wont, may she build there, and dwell,
And may thy armour be as it hath been,
Only thy valour and thine innocence,
What endless treasures would our enemies give,
That I might hold thee still thus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I am poor in words, but credit me young man
Thy mother could do no more but weep, for joy to see thee
After long absence, all the wounds I have,
Fetched not so much away, nor all the cries
Of widowed mothers: but this is peace
And that was war.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Pardon thou holy god
Of marriage bed, and frown not, I am forced
In answer of such noble tears as these,
To weep upon my wedding day.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I fear thou art grown too cruel, for I hear
A lady mourns for thee, men say to death,
Forsaken of thee, on what terms I know not.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: She had my promise, but the King forbade it,
And made me make this worthy change, thy sister
Accompanied with graces about her,
With whom I long to lose my lusty youth,
And grow old in her arms.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: My lord the masker's rage for you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: We are gone,
Cleon, Strato, Diphilus.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: We'll all attend you, we shall trouble you
With our solemnities.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Not so Amintor.
But if you laugh at my rude carriage
In sports, I'll do as much for you in war
When you come thither, but I have a mistress
To bring to your delights, rough though I am,
I have a mistress and she has a heart
she says, but trust me, it is stone, no better,
There is no place that I can challenge gentlemen,
But you stand still, and here my way lies. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Diagoras look to the doors better for shame, you let in all the world, and anon the King will be angry with me, why very well said, by Jove the King will have the show o'th the court;

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.l: Why do you swear so my lord,
You know he'll have it here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: By this light if he be wise, he will not.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: And if he will not be wise, you are forsworn.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: One must sweat out his heart with swearing, and get
Thanks on no side, I'll be gone, look to't who will.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.l: My lord I shall never keep them out,
Your looks will terrify them.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My looks terrify them, you coxcombly ass, I'll be judge by all the company, whether thou hast not a worse face than I.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: I mean because they know you, and your office.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Office, I would I could put it off, I am sure I sweat quite through in my office, I might have made room at my daughter's wedding, they ha' near killed her amongst them. But now I must do service for him that hath forsaken her, serve that will. Exit Calianax,

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: He's so humorous since his daughter was forsaken? hark, hark, who's there, codes, codes, what now?Within knock within

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: I hope your lordship brings no troop, for if you do, I must return them. Enter Melantius and a lady.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p:
The ladies are all placed above, save those that come in the King's troop, the best of Rhodes sit there,
●●ere is no room.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I thank you sir, when I have seen you placed madam, I must attend the King, but the mask done, I'll wait on you again. Exit Melantius' lady other door.

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: Stand back there, room for my lord Melantius, pray bear back, this is no place for such youths and their trulls, let the doors shut again, no; do your heads itch, I'll scratch them, so now thrust and hang, again, who is't now, I cannot blame my lord Calianax for giving way, would he were here, he would run raging amongst them, and break a dozen heads in the twinkling of an eye, what's the news now? WithinI pray you can you help me to the speech of the master cook?

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: If I open the door I'll cook some of your calf's heads. Peace rogues? — again, — who is't?

sp.speaker: Diag.
sp.p: O my lord a must, make room there for my lord, is your lady placed. Enter Melantius.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yes sir, I thank you, my lord Calianax, well met,
Your causeless hate to me I hope is buried.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes I do service for your sister here,
That brings mine own poor child to timeless death,
She loves your friend Amintor, such another false hearted
Lord as you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You do me wrong,
A most unmanly one, and I am slow
In taking vengeance, be well advised.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: It may be so, who placed the lady there.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: My lord she must not sit there.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The place is kept for women of more worth.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: More worth than she, it misbecomes your age,
And place to be so womanish, forbear,
What you have spoke I am content to think
the palsy shook your tongue to.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis well if I stand here to place men's wenches.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I shall quite forget this place, thy age, my safety, and through all cut that poor sickly week thou hast to live, away from thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay I know you can fight for your whore.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Bate me the King, and be of flesh and blood
'A lies that says it, thy mother at fifteen
Was black and sinful to her.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Some god pluck threescore years from that fond man,
That I may kill him, and not stain mine honour,
It is the curse of soldiers that in peace,
They shall be braved by such ignoble men,
As (If the land were troubled,) would with tears
And knees beg succour from 'em, would the blood
(That sea of blood) that I have lost in fight,
Were running in thy veins, that it might make thee
Apt to say less, and able to maintain,
Shouldst thou say more, — this Rhodes I see is naught
But a place privileged to do men wrong.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Ay, you may talk your pleasure. Enter Amintor.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: What vild wrong
Has stirred my worthy friend, who is as slow
To fight with words as he is quick of hands,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That heap of age, which I should reverence,
If it were temperate, but testy years
Are most contemptible.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: There is just such another as yourself.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: He will wrong you, or me, or any man,
And talk as if he had no life to lose
Since this our match: the King is come in,
I would not for more wealth than I enjoy
He should perceive you raging, he did hear
You were at difference now, which hastened him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.stage: Enter King Euadne, Aspatia, lords and ladies.
sp.l: Melantius thou art welcome, and thy love
Is with me still; but this is not a place
To brabble in, Calianax, join hands.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: He shall not have mine hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is no time
To force you to't I do love you both,
Calianax you look well to your office,
And you Melantius are welcome home,
Begin the mask.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sister I joy to see you, and your choice,
You looked with my eyes when you took that man,
Be happy in him.Recorders

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: O my dearest brother,
Your presence is more joyful than this day,

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Our reign is now, for in the quenching sea
The sun is drowned, and with him fell the day,
Bright Cinthia hear my voice, I am the night
For whom thou bearest about, thy borrowed light,
Appear, no longer thy pale visage shroud,
But strike thy silver horns quite through a cloud,
And send a beam upon my swarthy face,
By which I may discover all the place
And persons that have many longing eyes,
Are come to wait on our solemnities. Enter Cinthia.
How dull and black am I, can I not find
This beauty without thee, am I so blind,
Methinks they show like to those Eastern streaks,
That warn us hence before the morning breaks,
Back my pale servant, for these eyes know how,
To shoot far more and quicker rays than thou.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: Great Queen they be a troop for whom alone,
One of my clearest moons I have put on,
a troop that looks as if thyself and I,
Had plucked our reins in, and our whips laid by
To gaze upon those, that appear
Brighter than we.

sp.speaker: Nigh.
sp.l: Then let us keep 'em here,
And never more our chariots drive away,
But hold our places and outshine the day.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: Great Queen of shadows you are pleased to speak,
Of more than may be done, we may not break
The gods decrees, but when our time is come,
Must drive away and give the day our room.

sp.speaker: Nigh.
sp.l: Then shine at full pale Queen, and by that power,
Produce a birth to fill this happy hour,
Of nymphs and shepherds, and let their songs discover,
Easy and sweet who is a happy lover,
Or if thou wilt thine own Endymion
From the sweet flowery bank he lies upon,
On Latmus' brow thy pale beams drawn away▪
And of his long night let him make thy day.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: Thou dreamest dark power, that fair boy was not mine,
Not went I down to kiss him, ease and wind,
Have bred these bold tales, poets when they rage
Turns gods to men, and make an hour an age,
But I will give a greater state and glory,
And raise to time a nobler memory
Of what these lovers are, rise, rise, I say,
Thou power of deeps, thy surges laid away,
Neptune great King of waters, and by me
Be proud to be commanded. Neptune rises.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Cinthia see,
Thy word hath force me hither, let me know
Why I ascend.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: Doth this majestic show
Give thee no knowledge yet.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Yes, now I see,
Something intended Cinthia worthy thee,
Go on, I'll be a helper.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: Hie thee then,
And charge the wind go from his rocky den,
Let lose his subjects, only Boreas
Too foul for our intentions as he was,
Still keep him fast chained, we must have none here
But vernal blasts and gentle winds appear,
Such as blow flowers, and through the glad bows sing,
Many soft welcome to the lusty spring.
Bid them draw near to have thy watery race
Led on in couples, we are pleased to grace
This noble night each in their richest things,
Your own deeps or the broken vessels brings,
Be prodigal and I shall be as kind,
And shine at full upon you.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: See the windEnter Eolus out of a rock.
Commanding Aeolus.

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: We do command thee free,
Favonius and thy milder winds to wait
Upon our Cinthia, but tie Boreas straight,
He's rebellious.

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: Do master of the flould, and all below
Thy full command has taken

sp.speaker: Eol.
sp.l: O! the main
Neptune.

sp.speaker: Eol.
sp.l: Boreas has broke his chain,
And struggling with the rest has got away.

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: Let him alone I'll take him up at sea,
I will not be long thence, go hence again
And bid the other call out of the main,
Bl●w Proteus, and the rest, charge them put on
Their greatest pearls and the most sparkling stone
The beaten rock breeds, till this night is done,
by me a solemn honour to the moon,
Fly like a full sail.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: Dark night
Strike a full silence, do a thorough right
To this great chorus, that our music may
Touch high as heaven, and make the East break day
At midnight.Music

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Cinthia to thy power and thee
We obey,
Joy to this great company
And no day,
Come to steal this night away
Till the rights of love are ended,
And the lusty bridegroom say,
Welcome light of all befriended.
Pace out you watery powers below,
Let your feet
Like the galleys when they row
Even beat.
Let your unknown measures set
To the still winds, tell to all,
That gods are come immortal great,
To honour this great nuptial.

lg.head: The measure. Second song.
lg.l: Hold back thy hours old night till we have done,
The day will come too soon,
Young maids will curse thee if thou stealest away,
And leavest their losses open to the day,
Stay, stay, and hide
The blushes of the bride.
Stay gentle night and with thy darkness cover
The kisses of her lover.
Stay and confound her tears and her loud cryings,
her weak denials vows and often dyings,
Stay and hide all,
But help not if she call.

sp.speaker: Eol.
sp.l: The sea goes high,
Boreas has raised a storm, go and apply
Thy trident, else I prophesy ere day,
Many a tall ship will be cast away,
Descend with all the gods, and all their power
To strike a calm.

sp.speaker: Cinth.
sp.l: We thank you for this hour,
My favour to you all to gratulate
So great a service done at my desire,
Ye shall have many floods fuller and higher
Than you have wished for, and no ebb shall dare,
To let the day see where your dwellings are.
Now back unto your governments in haste,
Lest your proud waters should swell above the wa●t,
And win upon the island. Exeunt maskers descend.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: Hold up thy head dead night seest thou not day,
The East begins to lighten I must do●ne
And give my brother place.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.l: O I could frown
To see the day, the day that flings his light
Upon my kingdom, and contemns old night,
Let him go on, and ●lame, I hope to see
Another wild fire in his axletree,
And all fall drenched, but I forget, speak Queen,
The day grows on, I dare no more be seen.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: Once heave thy drowsy head again and see
A greater light a greater majesty
Between our sect and us, lash up thy team
The day breaks here, and yond sun flaring stream
Shot from the South, say which way wilt thou go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take light their ladies, get the bride to bed,
We will not see you laid, good night Amintor,
We'll ease you of that tedious ceremony,
Were it my case I should think time run slow
If thou beest noble youth, get me a boy
That may defend my kingdoms from my foes.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter Evadne, Aspatia, Dula, and other ladies.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: Madam shall we undress you for this fight,
The wars are naked that you must make tonight .

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: I should be far merrier madam, if it were with me
As it is with you.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: That I might go to bed with him with credit that you do.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: And as soon done,
Good store of clothes will trouble you at both.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Thou thinkst belike there is no modesty
When we're alone.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: I by my troth, you hit my thoughts right.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: Anon you must endure more and lie still,
'Tis best to practise.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: No faith, this is a trick that I have had
since I was fourteen.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: Nay now I'll keep it till the trick leave me,
A dozen wanton words put in your head,
Will make you livelier in your husband's bed.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: Take it madam, where,
We all will take it I hope that are here.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Nay then I'll give you o'er.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: So will I make
The ablest man in Rhodes or his heart ache.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Wilt lie in my place tonight .

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: I'll hold your cards against any two I know.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Madam we'll do't and make 'em leave play too.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: I will refuse it,
She will pluck down aside, she does not use it.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: You will find the play
Quickly, because your head lies well that way.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I thank thee Dula, would thou couldst instill
Some of thy mirth into Aspasia,
Nothing but sad thoughts in her breast do dwell,
Methinks a mean betwixt you would do well.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.l: She is in love, hang me if I were so,
But I could run my country I love too,
To do those things that people in love do.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: It were a timeless smile should prove my cheek,
It were a fitter hour for me to laugh,
When at the altar the religious priest,
Were pacifying the offended powers,
With sacrifice, than now, this should have been
My right, and all your hands have been employed,
In giving me a spotless offering
To young Amintor's bed, as we are now,
For you pardon Euadne, would my worth
were great as yours, or that the King or he
Or both thought so, perhaps he found me worthless,
But till he did so, in these ears of mine,
These credulous ears, he poured the sweetest words
That art or love could frame, if he were false
Pardon it heaven, and if I did want
Virtue, you safely may forgive that too,
For I have lost none that I had from you.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Nay leave this sad talk madam.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Would I could, than I should leave the cause.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Lo if you have not spoilt all Dula's mirth.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Thou thinkst thy heart hard, but if thou beest caught remember me; thou shalt perceive a fire shot suddenly unto thee.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: That's not so good, let 'em shoot any thing but sire, and I fear 'em not.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Well wench thou must be taken.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Lady's good night, I'll do the rest myself.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Nay let your lord do some.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Madam good night, may all the marriage joys
That longing maids imagine in their beds
Prove so unto you, may not discontent
Grow twixt your love and you, but if there do,
Inquire of me and I will guide your moan,
And teach you an artificial way to grieve,
To keep your sorrow waking, love your lord
No worse than I, but if you love so well,
Alas you may displease him, so did I,
This is the last time you shall look on me:
Ladies farewell, as soon as I am dead,
Come all and watch one night about my hearse.
Bring each a mournful story and a tear,
To offer at it when I go to earth;
With flattering ivy clasp my coffin round,
Write on my brow my fortune, let my beer
Be born by virgins that shall sing by course,
The truth of maids, and perjuries of men.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Alas I pity thee. Exit Euadne.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Come we'll let in the bridegroom.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.l: Here take this light,Enter Amintor.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: He'll find her in the dark.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Your lady's scarce a-bed , you must help her.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Go and be happy in your lady's love,
May all the wrongs that you have done to me,
Be utterly forgotten in my death,
I'll trouble you no more, yet I will take
A parting kiss, and will not be denied,
You'll come my lord and see the virgins weep,
When I am laid in earth; though you yourself
Can know no pity, thus I wind myself
Into this willow garland, and am prouder
That I was once your love, (Though now refused)
Then to have had another true to me.
So with prayers I leave you, and must try
Some yet unpractised way to grieve and die,

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Come ladies will you go. Exit Aspatia.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Much happiness unto you all. Exe: ladies.
I did that lady wrong, methinks I feel
A grief shoot suddenly through all my veins,
Mine eyes rain, this is strange at such a time,
It was the King first moved me to't, but he
Has not my will in keeping, — why did I
Perplex myself thus; something whispers me,
Go not to bed, my guilt is not so great
As mine own conscience, too sensible
Would make me think, I only break a promise,
And 'twas the King enforced me, timorous flesh,
Why shak'st thou so, away my idle fears,Enter Euadne
Yonder is she, the luster of whose eye,
Can blot away the sad remembrance
Of all these things: — o my Euadne spare
that tender body, let it not take cold,
The vapours of the night shall not fall here,
To bed my love, Hymen will punish us,
For being slack performers of his rights,
Camest thou to call me.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Come, come, my love,
And let us lose ourselves to one another,
Why art thou up so long.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: To bed, then let me wind thee in these arms,
Till I have banished sickness.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Good my lord I cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Euadne we'll watch, I mean no sleeping.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I will not for the world.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Why? I have sworn I will not.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Yes, sworn Amintor, and will swear again.
If you will wish to hear me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: To whom have you sworn this.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: If I should name him the matter were not great.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Come, this is but the coyness of a bride.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: How prettily that frown becomes thee.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Thou canst not dress thy face in such a look,
But I shall like it.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: What look will like you best.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: That I may show you one less pleasing to you,

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: That I may show you one less pleasing to you.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I prithee put thy jests in milder looks,
it shows as thou wert angry.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Why, who has done thee wrong,
Name me the man, and by thyself sweet love,
Thy yet unconquered self, I will revenge it.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Now I shall try thy truth, if thou dost love me.
Thou weigh'st not any thing compared to me,
Life, honour, joys eternal, all delights
The world can yield, are light as air
To a true lover when his lady frowns,
And bids him do this, wilt thou kill this man,
Swear my Amintor, and I'll kiss the sun
Of thy lips.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I wonot swear sweet love, till I know the cause.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I wood thou wouldst,
Why, it is thou that wrongest me, I hate thee,
Thou shouldst have killed thyself.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: If I should know that, I should quickly kill
The man you hated.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O no, what look soe'er thou shouldst put on,
To try my faith, I cannot think thee false,
I cannot find one blemish in thy face
Where falsehood should abide, leave, and to bed,
If you have sworn to any of the virgins
That were your old companions to preserve
Your maidenhead a night, it may be done
Without this means.

sp.speaker: Evad,
sp.p: A maidenhead Amintor at my years.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Sure she raves, this cannot be,
Her natural temper, shall I call thy maids,
Either thy healthful sleep hath left thee long,
Or else some fever rages in thy blood.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Neither of these, what think you I am mad,
Because I speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Is this the truth, will you not lie with me tonight .

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: You talk as if you thought I would hereafter.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You are deceived, put off amazement and with patience mark,
What I shall utter, for the oracle
Knows nothing truer 'tis not for a night
Or two that I forbear your bed, but ever.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: You hear right,
I sooner would find out the beds of snakes,
And with my youthful blood warm their cold flesh,
Letting them curl themselves about my limbs,
Then sleep one night with thee; this is not feigned,
Nor sounds it like the kisses of a bride.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Is flesh so earthly to endure all this,
Are these the joys of marriage, Hymen keep
This story (That will make succeeding youth
Neglect thy ceremonies) from all ears.
Let it not rise up for thy shame and mine
To after ages, we will scorn thy laws,
If thou no better bless them, touch the heart
Of her whom thou hast sent me, or the world
Shall know this, not an altar then will smoke
In praise of thee, we will adopt us sons,
Than virtue shall inherit and not blood,
If we do lust, we'll take the next we meet;
Serving ourselves as other creatures do,
And never take note of the female more,
Nor of her issue: I do rage in vain,
She cannot jest; o pardon me my love,
So dear the thoughts are which I hold of thee,
That I must break forth; satisfy my fear,
It is a pain beyond the pain of death,
To be in doubt; confirm it with an oath,
If this be true.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Do you invent the form,
Let there be in it all the binding words
Devils and conjurers can put together,
And I will take it, I have sworn before,
and here by all things holy do again,
Never to be acquainted with thy bed,
Is your doubt over now.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I know too much, would I had doubted still,
Was ever such a marriage night as this:
You powers above, if you did ever mean
Man should be used thus, you have thought a way
How he may bear himself, and save his honour:
Instant me with it, for to my dull eyes
There is no mean, no moderate course to run,
I must live scorned or be a murderer:
Is there a third, why is this night so calm,
Why does not heaven speak in thundet to us,
And drown their voice.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: This rage will do no good.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Euadne, hear me, thou hast ta'en an oath,
But such a rash one, that to keep it were
Worse than to swear it, call it back to thee,
Such vows as that never ascend the heaven,
A tear or two will wash it quite away,
Have mercy on my youth, my hopeful youth,
If thou be pitiful, for without boast
This land was proud of me, what lady was there
That men called fair, and virtuous in this isle
That would have shunned my love, it is in thee
To make me hold this worth — o we vain men
That trust all our reputation
To rest upon the weak and yielding hand
Of feeble woman, but thou art not stone,
Thy flesh is soft, and in thine eyes do dwell
The spirit of love, thy heart cannot be hard,
Come lead me from the bottom of despair,
To all the joys thou hast, I know thou wilt.
And make me careful lest the sudden change
O'ercome my spirits.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: When I call back this oath, the pains of hell environ me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I sleep and am too temperate, come to bed,
Or by those hairs which if thou hast a soul; like to thy locks,
Were threads for Kings to wear
About their arms.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I'll drag thee to my bed, and make thy tongue
Undo this wicked oath, or on thy flesh
I'll print a thousand wounds to let out life.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I fear thee not, do what thou dar'st to me,
Every ill sounding word, or threatening look
Thou showest to me, will be revenged at full.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Alas Amintor thinkst thou I forbear
To sleep with thee, because I have put on
A maiden's strictness, look upon these cheeks,
And thou shalt find the hot and rising blood
Unapt for such a vow, no, in this heart
There dwells as much desire, and as much will,
To put that wished act, as ever yet
Was known to woman, and they have been shown
Both, but it was the folly of thy youth,
To think this beauty, to what land soe'er
It shall be called, shall stoop to any second,
I do enjoy the best, and in that height
Have sworn to stand or die, you guess the man.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: No, let me know the man that wrongs me so▪
That I may cut his body into motes,
And scatter it before the Northern wind.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do not wrong me so,
Yes, if his body were a poisonous plant,
That it were death to touch, I have a soul
Will throw me on him.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: What did he make this match for dull Amintor.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O thou hast named a word that wipes away
All thoughts revengeful, in that sacred word,
The King, there lies a terror, what frail man
Dares lift his hand against it, let the gods
Speak to him when they please, till when let us
Suffer, and wait.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Why should you fill yourself so full of heat,
And haste so to my bed, I am no virgin.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: What devil hath put it in thy fancy then
To marry me.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Alas, I must have one
To father children, and to bear the name
Of husband to me, that my sin may be
More honourable.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: What strange thing am I?
A miserable one, one that myself
Am sorry for.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Why show it then in this,
If thou hast pity, though thy love be none,
Kill me, and all true lovers that shall love
In after ages crossed in their desires,
Shall bless thy memory, and call thee good,
Because such mercy in thy breast was found,
To rid a lingering wretch.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I must have one
To fill thy room again if thou wert dead,
Else by this night I could, I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: These strange and sudden injuries have fallen
So thick upon me, that I lose all sense
Of what they are, methinks I am not wronged,
Nor is it ought, if from the censuring world
I can but hide it — reputation
Thou art a word, no more, but thou hast shown
An impudence so high, that to the world
I fear thou wilt betray or shame thyself.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: To cover shame, I took thee never fear,
That I would blaze myself.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Nor let the King
Know I conceive he wrongs me, than mine honour
Will thrust me into action, that my flesh
Could bear with patience, and it is some ease
To me in these extremes, that I know this
Before I touched thee, else had all the sins
Of mankind stood betwixt me and the King,
I had gone through, e'en to his heart and thine
I have left one desire, 'tis not his crown
Shall buy me to thy bed, now I resolve
He has dishonoured thee, give me thy hand,
Be careful of thy credit, and sin close
'Tis all I wish, upon thy chamber flower
I'll rest tonight , that morning visiters
May think we did as married people use,
And prithee smile upon me when they come,
And seem to toy as if thou hadst been pleased
With what I did.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Fear not, I will do this.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Come let us practise, and as wantonly
As ever longing bride and bridegroom met,
Let's laugh and enter here.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I am content.
Down all the swellings of my troubled heart,
When we walk thus entwined let all eyes see,
If ever lovers better did agree. Exit.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Away you are not, force it no further,
Good, good, how well you look, such a full colour
Young bashful brides put on, sure you are new married.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Alas poor wenches
Go learn to love first, learn to lose yourselves,
Learn to be flattered, and believe and bless
the double tongue that did it,
Did you ere love yet wenches, speak Olimpas,
Thou hast a mettled temper, fit for stamp.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Then my good girls be more than women wise
At least, be more than I was, come let's be sad my girls,
That down cast of thine eye Olimpias,
Shows a feigned sorrow; mark Antiphila,
Just such another was the nymph Oenone's,
When Paris brought home Helen, now a tear,
And than thou art a piece expressing fury,
The Carthage Queen when from a cold sea rock,
Full with her sorrow, she tied fast her eyes,
To the fair Trojan ships, having lost them,
Just as thine does, down stole a tear! Antiphila,
What would this wench do if she were Aspasia,
Here she would stand, till some more, pitying god
Turned her to marble, 'tis enough my wench,
Show me the piece of needle work you wrought.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Yes that piece,
This should be Theseus, has a cozening face,
You meant him for a man.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Why then 'tis well enough, never look black,
You have a full wind, and a false heart Theseus,
Does not the story say, his keel was split,
Or his masts spent, or some kind rock or other
Met with his vessel.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: It should ha' been so, could the gods know this,
And none of all their number raise a storm,
But they are all as ill, this false smile was expressed well,
Just such another caught me, you shall not go so
Antiphila, in this place work a quicksand,
And over it a shallow smiling water,
and over it a shallow smiling water,
And his ship ploughing it, and then a fear,
Do that fear bravely wench.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: 'Twill make the story, wronged by wanton poets,
Live long and be believed, but where's the lady.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Fie, you have missed it there Antipila,
You are much mistaken wench:
These colours are not dull and pale enough,
To show a soul so full of misery
As this poor ladies was, do it by me,
Do it again, by me the lost Aspasia,
And you will find all true but the wild island,
Suppose I stand upon the sea, breach now
Mine arms thus, and mine hair blown with the wind,
Wild as the place she was in, let all about me
Be tears of my story, do my face,
If thou hadst ever feeling of a sorrow,
Thus, thus, Antiphila make me look good girl
Like sorrows mount, and the trees about me
Let them be dry and leaveless, let the rocks
Groan with continuall surges, and behind me
Make all a desolation, see, see wenches,
A miserable life of this poor picture.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: I have done, sit down, and let us
Upon that point fix all our eyes, that point there▪
Make a dumb silence till you feel a sudden sadness
Give us new souls. Enter Calianax.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The King may do this, and he may not do it,
My child is wronged, disgraced, well, how now huswives,
What at your ease, is this a time to sit still, up you young
Lazy whores, up or I'll swinge you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You'll lie down shortly, in and whine there,
What are you grown so rusty you want hea●e●,
we shall have some of the court boys heat you shortly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good my lord be not angry, we do nothing
But what my lady's pleasure is, we are thus in grief,
She is forsaken. ●

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There's a rogue too,
A sly dissembling slave, well? get you in,
I'll have about with that boy, 'tis high time
Now to be valiant, I confess my youth
Was never prone that way,
A court stale, well I must be valiant,
And beat some dozen of these whelps, and there's
Another of 'em, a trim cheating soldier,
I'll maul that rascal, has outbraved me twice,
But now I thank the gods I am valiant,
Go, get you in, I'll take a course with all. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your sister is not up yet.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: Our brides must take their morning's rest,
The night is troublesome.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: What odds, he has not my sister's maidenhead tonight .

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: None, its odds against any bridegroom living, he ne'er gets it while he lives.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: You're merry with my sister, you'll please to allow me the same freedom with your mother.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Then she's merry enough of herself, she needs no tickling, knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: No matter they have the year before them, good morrow sister, spare yourself today, the night will come again. Enter Amintor.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Who's there my brother, I am no readier yet, your sister is but now up.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p:
You look as you had lost your eyes tonight , I
think you ha' not slept.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: We have ventured for a boy, when he is twelve, 'a shall command against the foes of Rhodes, shall we be merry.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You cannot, you want sleep,

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: 'Tis true, but she
As if she had drunk Lethe, or had made
Even with heaven, did fetch so still a sleep,Aside.
So sweet and sound.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Your sister frets this morning, and doth turn her eyes upon me, as people on the headsman, she does chafe, and kiss and chafe, and clap my cheeks, she's in another world.

sp.speaker: Dip.
sp.p: Then I had lost, I was about to lay, you had not got● her maiden head tonight .

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Ha, does he not mock me, y'ad lost indeed I do not bungle.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I laid my lips to hers, and that wild breach
That was so rude and rough to me, last night
Was sweet as April, I'll be guilty too,
If these be the effects. Enter Melantius.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Good day Amintor, for to me the name
Of brother is too distant, we are friends,
And that is nearer.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Dear Melantius,
Let me behold thee, is it possible.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why does thine eye desire so strict a view
Of that it knows so well? there's nothing here
That is not thine.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I wonder much Melantius.
To see those noble looks that make more think,
how virtuous thou art, and on this sudden
'Tis strange to me, thou shouldst have worth and honour,
Or not be base and false, and treacherous,
And every ill.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Say, stay my friend,
I fear this sound will not become our loves, no more embrace me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O mistake me not,
I know thee to be full of all those deeds,
That we frail men call good, but by the course
Of nature thou shouldst be as quickly changed,
As are the winds dissembling, as the sea,
That now wears brows as smooth as virgins be,
Tempting the merchant to invade his face.
And in an hour call his billows up,
And shoot 'em at the sun, destroying all
'A carries on him, o how near am I
To utter my sick thoughts.Aside.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why, my friend, should I be so by nature?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I have wed thy sister, who hath virtuous thoughts enough for one whole family, and it is strange,
That you should feel no want.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Believe me this is compliment too cunning for me.

sp.speaker: Dip.
sp.l: What should I be then by the course of nature,
They having both robbed me of so much virtue.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: O call the bride my lord Amintor, that we may see her blush, and turn her eyes down, it is the prittiest sport.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Come forth my love,
Your brothers do attend to wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Enough, enough,

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Faith thou shalt come in. Enter Euadne.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Good morrow sister, he that understands
Whom you have wed, need not to wish you joy,
you have enough, take heed you be not proud.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: O sister what have you done.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: My lord Amintor swears you are no maid now.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I knew I should be mocked.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: If 'twere to do again, in faith I would not marry.

sp.speaker: Dip.
sp.p: Sister, Dula swears she heard you cry two rooms off.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Who I, I thank you for that, shall Diphilus thou and I sing a catch.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay that▪ too much the other way●

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I am so heightened with my happiness, how dost thou love, kiss me.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I cannot love you, you tell tales of me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Nothing but what becomes us, gentlemen
Would you had all such wives, and all the world,
That I might be no wonder, you're all sad,
What do you envy me, I walk methinks
On water, and ne'er sink I am so light.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Well? can you be other when she looks thus,
Is there no music there, let's dance.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I do not know myself, yet I could wish my joy were less.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: I'll marry if it will make one thus

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What says my love I must obey.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: You do it scuruily, 'twill be perceived.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My lord the King is here. Enter King and Lisip:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good morrow all.
Amintor joy on joy fall thick upon thee,
But madam you are altered since I saw you,
I must salute you, you are now another's,
How liked you your night's rest.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You'll let her take more, etc. thank her too shortly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Amintor wert thou truly honest till thou wert married.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Tell me how then shows the sport to you.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: No more nor less than other couples use,
You know what 'tis, it has but a course name▪

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But prithee I should think by her black eye
And her red cheek, she should be quick and stirring
In this same business; ha?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I cannot tell I ne'er tried other sir, but I perceive
She is as quick as you delivered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well you'll trust me then Amintor,
To choose a wife for you again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why? like you this so ill.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: So well I like her,
For this I bow my knee in thanks to you,
And unto heaven will pay my grateful tribute
Hourly, and do hope we shall draw out,
A long contented life together here,
And die both full of grey hairs in one day,
For which the thanks is yours, but if the powers
That rule us, please to call her first away,
Without pride spoke, this world holds not a wife
Worthy to take her room.Aside

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not like this; all forbear the room
But you Amintor and your lady, I have some speech that may
Concern your after living well▪

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: 'A will not tell me that he lies with her, if he do,
For it is apt to thrust this arm of mine to acts unlawful.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You will suffer me to talk with her Amintor,
And not have jealous pangs.

sp.speaker: Amin,
sp.l: Sir, I dare trust my wife,
When she dares to talk, and not be jealous

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: As one that to fulfil your pleasure,
I have given leave to call me wife and love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I see there is no lasting faith in sin,
They that break word with heaven, will break again
With all the world, and so dost thou with me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This subtle woman's ignorance
Will not excuse you, thou hast taken oaths
So great, that methought they did misbecome
A woman's mouth, that thou wouldst ne'er enjoy
A man but me.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I never did swear so, you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Day and night have heard it.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I swore indeed that I would never love
A man of lower place, but if your fortune
Should throw you from this height, I bade you trust
I would forsake you, and would bend to him
That won your throne, I love with my ambition,
Not with my eyes, but if I ever yet
Touched any other, leprosy light here
Upon my face, which for your royalty
I would not stain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why thou dissemblest, and it is in me
To punish thee.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Why, it is in me then, not to love you, which will
More afflict your body, than your punishment can mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But thou hast let Amintor lie with thee.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: By this light he does, strangely and basely, and
I'll prove it so, I did not only shun him for a night,
But told him I would never close with him.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: I am no man to answer with a blow,
Or if I were, you are the King, but urge not, 'tis most true.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Do not I know the uncontrolled thoughts,
That youth brings with him, when his blood is high,
With expectation and desire of that
He long hath waited for, is not his spirit
Though he be temperate, of a valiant strain
As this our age hath known, what could he do
If such a sudden speech had met his blood,
But ruin thee for ever, if he had not killed thee
He could not bear it thus, he is as we
Or any other wronged man.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: This is dissembling,
Amintor, thou hast an ingenious look,
And shouldst be virtuous, it amazeth me
That thou shouldst make such base malicious lies.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Dear wife, I do despise thee,
Why nothing can be baser than to sow
Dissension amongst lovers,

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Who should live long and love without distaste,
Were it not for such pick-thanks as thyself,
Did you lie with me, swear now, and be punished in hell
For this.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: The faithless sin I made
To fair Aspatia, is not yet revenged,
It follows me, I will not lose a word
To this wild woman, but to you my King,
The anguish of my soul thrusts out this truth,
you're a tyrant, and not so much to wrong
An honest man thus, as to take a pride
In talking with him of it.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Now sir, see how loud this fellow lies.

sp.speaker: A●in.
sp.l: You that can know to wrong, should know how
Men must right themselves, what punishment is due,
From me to him that shall abuse my bed,
It is not death, nor can that satisfy,
Unless I show how nobly I have freed myself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Draw not thy sword, thou knowest I cannot fear
A subject's hand, but thou shalt feel the weight
Of this if thou dost rage.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: The wait of that,
If you have any worth, for heaven's sake think
I fear not swords, for as you are mere man,
I dare as easily kill you for this deed,
As you dare think to do it, but there is.
Divinity about you, that strikes dead
My rising passions, as you are my King,
I fall before you and present my sword,
To cut mine own flesh if it be your will,
Alas! I am nothing but a multitude of
Walking griefs, yet should I murder you,
I might before the world take the excuse
Of madness, for compare my injuries,
And they will well appear too sad a weight
For reason to endure, but fall I first
Amongst my sorrows, ere my treacherous sword
Touch holy things, but why? I know not what
I have to say, why did you choose out me
To make thus wretched, there are thousands
Easy to work on, and of state enough
Within the land.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I would not have a fool, it were no credit for me●

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Worse and worse,
Thou that dar'st talk unto thy husband thus,
Profess thyself a whore, and more than so,
resolve to be so still, is it my fault,
To bear and bow beneath a thousand griefs,
To keep that little credit with the world,
But there were wise ones to, you might have ta'en another.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: No, for I believe thee honest, as thou wert valiant.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: All the happiness
Bestowed upon me turns into disgrace,
Gods take your honesty again, for I
Am loaden with it, good my lord the King
Be private in it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou mayst live Amintor,
Free as thy King, if thou wilt wink at this,
And be a means that we may meet in secret,

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A bawd, hold, hold my breast, a bitter curse
Cease me, if I forget not all respects
That are religious, on another word
Seconded like that, and through a sea of sins
Will wade to my revenge, though I should call
Plagues here, and after life, upon my soul.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, I am resolute, you lay with her,
And so I leave you. Exit King.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: You must needs be prating, and see what follows.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Prithee vex me not,
Leave me, I am afraid some sudden start
Will pull a murder on me.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: I am gone, I love my life well. Exit Euadne.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I hate mine as much,
This 'tis to break a troth, I should be glad,
If all this tide of grief would make me mad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I'll know the cause of all Amintor's griefs,
Or friendship shall be idle. Enter Calianax.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O Melantius, my daughter will die.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Trust me I am sorry, would thou hadst ta'en her part.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou art a slave, a cutthroat slave, a bloody —

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Take heed old man, thou wilt be heard to rave,
And lose thine office.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am valiant grown,
At all these years, and thou art but a slave.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Some company will come, and I respect
Thy years, not thee so much, that I could wish
To laugh at thee alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll spoil your mirth, I mean to fight with thee,
There lie my cloak, this was my father's sword,
And he durst fight, are you prepared?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why? wilt thou dote thyself out of thy life, hence get thee to bed, have careful looking to, and eat warm things, and trouble not me, my head is full of thoughts, more weighty than thy life or death can be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You have a name in war, where you stand safer
Amongst a multitude, but I will try,
What you dare do unto a weak old man▪
In single fight you'll give ground I fear,
Come draw.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I will not draw, unless thou pull'st thy death
Upon thee with a stroke, there's no one blow
That thou canst give haste strength enough can kill me,
Tempt me not so far then, the power of earth
Shall not redeem thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I must let him alone,
He's stout, and able, and to say the truth,
However I may set a face and talk,
I am not valiant, when I was a youth
I kept my credit with a testy trick,
I had amongst cowards, but durst never fight.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I will not promise to preserve your life if you do stay.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I would give half my land that I durst fight with that proud man a little, if I had men to hold him, I would beat him, till he asked me mercy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
I dare not stay, but I will beat my servants all
over for this. Exit Calianax

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This old fellow haunts me,
But the distracted carriage of mine Amintor,
Takes deeply on me, I will find the cause,
I fear his conscience cries, he wronged Aspasia.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Man's eyes are not subtle to perceive
My inward misery, I bear my grief
Hid from the world, how art thou wretched then,
For ought I know all husbands are like me,
And every one I talk with of his wife,
Is but a well dissembler of his woes
As I am, would I knew it for the rareness
Afflicts me now.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Amintor, we have not enjoyed our friendship of late, for we were wont to charge our souls in talk.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Melantius, I can tell the a good jest of Strato, and a lady the last day.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I have longed to speak with you, not of an idle jest that's forced, but of matter you are bound to utter to me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I have observed your words fall from your tongue
Wildly, and all your carriage
Like one that strives to show his merry mood,
When he were ill disposed, you were not wont
To put such scorn into your speech — ye wear
Upon your face ridiculous jollity,
Some sadness sits here, which your tongue would
Cover o'er with smiles, and 'twill not be,
What is it?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A sadness here, what cause
Can fate provide for me to make me so,
Am I not loved through all this isle, the King
Reins greatness on me, have I not received
a lady to my bed, that in her eye
Keeps mounting fire, and on her tender cheeks
Immutable colour, in her heart
A prison for all virtue, are not you,
Which is above all joys, my constant friend:
What sadness can I have, no, I am light,
And feel the courses of my blood more warm
And stirring than they were; faith marry too,
And you will feel so unexpressed a joy
In chaste embraces, that you will indeed
Appear another.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You may shape Amintor
Causes to cozen the whole world withal,
And yourself too, and 'tis not like a friend,
To hide your soul from me, 'tis not your nature
To be thus idle, I have seen you stand,
As you were blasted midst of all your mirth,
Call thrice aloud, and then start, feigning joy
So coldly, world? what do I hear, a friend
Is nothing, heaven I would ha' told that man
My secret sins, I'll search an unknown ●and,
And there plant friendship, all is withered here,
Come with a compliment, I would have fought,
Or told my friends a lied, ere soothed him so;
Out of my bosom.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Worse and worse, farewell;
From this time have acquaintance, but no friend.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Melantius, stay, you shall know what that is.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: See how you plead with friendship, be advised
How you give cause unto yourself to say,
You ha' lost a friend.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Forgive what I ha' done,
For I am so o'ergone with miseries,
Unheard of, that I lose consideration
Of what I ought to do, — o — o.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do not weep, what is't?
May I once but know the man
Hath turned my friend thus.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I had spoke at first, but that,

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I held it most unfit
For you to know, faith do not know it yet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thou seest my love, that will keep company
With thee in tears, hide nothing then from me,
For when I know the cause of thy distemper,
With mine old armour I'll adorn myself,
My resolution, and cut through thy foes
Unto thy quiet, till I place thy heart
As peaceable as spotless innocence.
What is it?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Why 'tis this, — it is too big
To get out, let my tears make way awhile.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Punish me strangely heaven, if he scape
Of life or fame, that brought this youth to this.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: You'll wished unknown when you have heard it.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Is much to blame,
And to the King has given her honour up,
And lives in whoredom with him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: How's this?
Thou art run mad with injury indeed,
Thou couldst not utter this, else speak again,
For I forgive it freely, tell thy griefs.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She's wanton, I am loath to say a whore,
Though it be true.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Speak yet again, before mine anger grow
Up beyond throwing down, what are thy griefs?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What, am I sane,
After mine actions, shall the name of friend
Blot all our family, and stick the brand
of whore upon my sister unrevenged
My shaking flesh be thou a witness for me,
With what unwillingness I go to scourge
This railer, whom my folly hath called friend,
I will not take thee basely, thy sword
Hangs near thy hand, draw it, that I may whip
Thy rashness to repentance, draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Not on thee, did thine anger go as high
As troubled waters, thou shouldst do me ease,
Here, and eternally, if thy noble hand,
Would cut me from my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This is base,
And fearful, they that use to utter lies,
Provide not blows, but words to qualify
The men they wronged, thou hast a guilty cause.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Thou pleasest me, for so much more like this,
Will raise my anger up above my griefs,
Which is a passion easier to be known,
And I shall then be blessed.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Take then more, to raise thine anger, 'tis mere
Cowardice makes thee not draw, and I will leave thee dead
However , but if thou art so much pressed,
With guilt and fear, as not to dare to fight,
I'll make thy memory loathed, and fix a farewell
Upon thy name for ever.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Then I draw,
As justly as our magistrates their swords,
To cut offenders off; I knew before,
'Twould grate your ears, but it was base in you
To urge a weighty secret from your friend,
And then rage at it, I shall be at ease
If I be killed, and if you fall by me,
I shall not long out live you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Stay a while,
The name of friend, is more than family,
Or all the world besides; I was a fool,
Thou searching humane nature, that didst make
to do me wrong thou art inquisitive,
And thrusts me upon questions that will take
My sleep away, would I had died ere known
This sad dishonour, pardon me my friend,
If thou wilt strike, here is a faithful heart,
Pierce it, for I will never heave my hand
To thine, behold the power thou hast in me,
I do believe my sister is a whore,
A leprous one, put up thy sword young man.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: How should I bear it then she being so,
I fear my friend that you will lose me shortly,
And I shall do a foul act on myself
Through these disgraces.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Better half the la●d
Were buried quick together, no Amintor,
Thou shalt have ease of this adulterous King
That drew her to't, where got he the spirit
To wrong me so.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: What is it then to me?
If it be wrong to you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why not so much, the credit of our house
Is thrown away,
But from his iron den I'll waken death,
And hurl him on this King, my honesty
Shall steel my sword, and on my horrid point
I'll wear my cause, that shall amaze the eyes
Of this proud man, and be to glittering
For him to look on.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I have quite undone my fame.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Dry up thy watery eyes,
And cast a manly look upon my face,
For nothing is so wild as I thy friend
Till I have freed thee, still this swelling breast,
I go thus from thee, and will never cease
My vengeance till I find thy heart at peace.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: It must not be so, stay, mine eyes would tell
How loath I am to this, but love and tears
leave me a while, for I have hazarded
All that this world calls happy, thou hast wrought
A secret from me under name of friend,
Which art could ne'er have found, nor torture wrong
From out this bosom, give it me again,
For I will find it wheresoe'er it lies
Hid in the mortalest part, invent a way
To give it back.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why? would you have it back,
I will to death pursue him with revenge.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Therefore I call it from thee, for I know
Thy blood so high, that thou wilt stir in this, take to thy weapon

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hear thy friend that bears more years than thou.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I will not hear, but draw, or I —

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Draw then, for I am full as resolute
As fame, and honour can enforce me,
I cannot linger, draw?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I do, — but is not
My share of credit equal with thine
If I do stir.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: No? for it will be called
Honour in thee to spill thy sister's blood,
If she her birth abuse, and on the King
A brave revenge, but on me that have walked
With patience in it, it will fix the name
Of fearful cuckold, — oh that word,
Be quick.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I dare not do a sin, or else I would be speedy.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Then dare not fight with me, for that's a sin,
His grief distracts him, call thy thoughts again,
And to thyself pronounce the name of friend,
And see what that will work, I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I will be killed first, though my passions
Offered the like to you, 'tis not this earth
shall by my reason to it, think awhile
For you are, (I must weep when I speak it,)
All most besides yourself.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my soft temper,
So many sweet words from thy sister's mouth,
I am afraid would make me take her,
To embrace and pardon her, I am mad indeed,
And know not what I do, but have a care
Of me in what thou dost.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why thinks my friend I will forget his honour, or to save
The bravery of your house, will lose his fame
And fear to touch the throne of majesty.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A curse will follow that, but rather live
And suffer with me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I will do what worth shall bid me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Faith I am sick, and desperately I hope,
Yet leaning thus I feel a kind of ease.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come take again your mirth about you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I warrant you, look up, we'll walk together,
Put thine arm here, all shall be well again.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Thy love, oh wretched, I thy love Melantius, why I
Have nothing else. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be merry then. Enter Melantius again.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This worthy young man may do violence
Upon himself, but I have cherished him
As well as I could, and sent him smiling from me
To counterfeit again, sword hold thine edge,
My heart will never fail me? Diphilus,
Thou com'st as sent. Enter Diphilus.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: Why our sister and the King,
I thought their spleens would break,
They laughed us all out of the room.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: They must? thou art my brother, and if I did believe,
Thou hadst a base thought, I would ●ip it out,
Lie where it durst.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: You should not, I would first mangle myself and find it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That was spoke according to our strain, come join thy hands,
And swear a firmness to what project ●
Shall lay before thee.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: You do wrong us both,
People hereafter shall not say there passed
A bond more than our loves to tie our lives
And deaths together.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: It is as nobly said as I would wish,
Anon I'll tell you wonders, we are wronged.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: But I will tell you now, we'll right ourselves.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Stay not, prepare the armour in my house,
And what friends you can draw unto our side,
Not knowing of the cause, make ready too,
Hast Diph: the time requires it, haste. Exit Diphilus.
I hope my cause is just, I know my blood
Tells me it is, and I will credit it,
To take revenge and lose myself withal,
Were idle, and to scape, impossible,
Without I had the ●ort, which misery
Remaining in the hands of my old enemy
Calianax, but I must have it, seeEnter Calianax.
Where he comes shaking by me, good my lord
Forget your spleen to me, I never wronged you,
But would have peace with every man.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis well?
If I durst ●ight, your tongue would lie at quiet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By mine honour I speak truth.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: See what starts you make into your idle hatred.
I am come with resolution to obtain a suit
of you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: A suit of me, 'tis very like it should be granted sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Nay, go not hence,
'Tis this, you have the keeping of the fort,
And I would wish you by the love you ought
To bear unto me to deliver it
Into my hands.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I am in hope thou art mad, to talk to me thus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But there is a reason to move you to it, I would
Kill the King, that wronged you and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Nay but stay, I cannot scape the deed once done
Without I have this fort.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And should I help thee, now thy treacherous mind betrays itself.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come delay me not,
Give me a sudden answer, already,
The last is spoke, refuse my offered love,
When it comes clad in secrets.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If I say I will not, he will kill me, I do see't writ
In his looks, and should I say I will, he'll run and tell the
King: I do not shun your friendship dear Melantius,
But this cause is weighty, give me but an hour to think.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Take it, — I know this goes unto the King,
But I am armed. Exit Melantius.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Methinks I feel myself
But twenty now again, this fighting fool
Wants policy, I shall revenge my girl,
And make her red again, I pray, my legs
Will last that pace that I will carry them,
I shall want breath before I find the King,

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Melantius, Evadne, and a lady.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Save you sweet brother,

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: In my blunt eye methinks you look Euadne.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Come, you would make, me blush.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I would Euadne, I shall displease my ends else.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: You shall if you command me, I am bashful,
Come sir, how do I look.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I would not have your women hear me
Break into a commendations of you, it is not seemly.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Go wait me in the gallery, — now speak.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'll lock your doors first. Exit ladies

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I will not have your guilded things that dance
In visitation with their Milan skins
Choke up my business.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good madam, not to make you merry.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: No, if you praise me 'twill make me sad.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Such a sad commendations I have for you.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Brother, the court has made you witty,
And learn to riddle.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I praise the court for't, has learned you nothing.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I Euadne, thou art young and handsome,
A lady of a sweet complexion,
And such a flowing carriage, that it cannot
Choose but inflame a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis yet in thy repentance, foolish woman,
To make me gentle.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis base,
And I could blush at these years, through all
My honoured scars: to come to such a parley.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You dare not fool,
They that commit thy faults fly the remembrance.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: My faults sir, I would have you know I care not
If they were written here, here in my forehead.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thy body is too little for the story,
The lusts of which would fill another woman,
Though she had twins within her.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: This is saucy,
Look you intrude no more, there's your way.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thou art my way, and I will tread upon thee,
Till I find truth out.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: What truth is that you look for?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thy long lost honour, would the gods had set me
Rather to grapple with the plague, or stand
One of their loudest bolts, come tell me quickly,
Do it without enforcement, and take heed
You swell me not above my temper.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: How sir? where got you this report.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Where there was people in every place.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: They and the seconds of it are base people,
Believe them not, they'll lie.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do not play with mine anger, do not wretch,
I come to know that desperate fool, that drew thee
From thy fair life, be wise and lay him open.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Unhand me and learn manners, such another
Forgetfulness forfeits your life.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Quench me this mighty humour, and then tell me
Whose whore you are, for you are one, I know it,
Let all mine honours perish but I'll find him,
Though he lie locked up in thy blood, come tell me,
There is no facing it, and be not flattered,
The burned air when the dog reigns, is not fouler
Than thy contagious name, till thy repentance,
If the gods grant thee any, purge thy sickness.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Begun, you are my brother that's your safety.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I'll be a wolf first, 'tis to be thy brother
An infamy below the sin of coward,
I am as far from being part of thee,
As thou art from thy virtue, seek a kindred
Amongst sensual beasts, and make a goat thy father,
A goat is cooler, will you tell me yet.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: If you stay here and rail thus, I shall tell you,
I'll ha' you whipped, get you to your command,
And there preach to your sentinels,
And tell them what a brave man you are, I shall laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You're grown a glorious whore, where be your
Fighters, what mortal fool durst raise thee to this daring,
And I alive, by my just sword, he'd safer
Bestride a billow when the angry North
Ploughs up the sea, or made heaven's fire his foe,
Work me no hire, will you discovery yet.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: The fellows mad, sleep and speak sense.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Force my swollen heart no further, I would save thee, your great maintainers are not here, they dare not, would they were all, and armed, I would speak loud, here's one should thunder to 'em, will you tell me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do, whose child thou wert,
Whose honour thou hast murdered, whose grave opened,
And so pulled on the gods, that in their justice
They must restore him flesh again and life,
And raise his dry bones to revenge this scandal.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: The gods are not of my mind, they had better
Let 'em lie sweet still in the earth, they'll stink here.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do you raise mirth out of my easiness,
Forsake me then all weaknesses of nature,
That make men women, speak you whore, speak truth,
Or by the dear soul of thy sleeping father,
This sword shall be thy lover, tell or I'll kill thee,
And when thou hast told all, thou wilt deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No, 'tis a justice and a noble one,
To put the light out of such base offenders.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: By thy foul self, no human help shall help thee,
If thou criest, when I have killed thee, as I have
Vowed to do, if thou confess not, naked as thou hast left
Thine honour, will I leave thee,
that on thy branded flesh the world may read
Thy black shame and my justice, wilt thou bend yet?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis true, thou art, speak truth still.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: I have offended, noble sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Do not ask me sir,
Mine own remembrance is a misery
Too mighty for me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Do not fall back again▪ my sword's unsheathed yet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be true, and make your fault less.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Tell, or I'll be this day a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Stay I must ask mine honour first, I have too much foolish nature in me, speak.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: None but a fearful conscience, that's too many.
Who is't?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My worthy fathers and my services
Are liberally rewarded, King I thank thee:
For all my dangers and my wounds thou hast paid me
In my own metal, these are soldiers thanks.
How long have you lived thus Euadne?

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: Too long, too late I find it.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: Would I were half as blameless.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Woman thou wilt not to thy trade again.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Would gods thou hadst been so blessed.
Dost thou not hate this King now? prithee hate him.
Has sunk thy fair soul, I command thee curse him,
Curse till the gods hear and deliver him
to thy just wishes, yet I fear Euadne
You had rather play your game out.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: No I feel
Too many sad confusions here to let in
Any loose flame hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Dost thou not feel amongst all those one brave anger
That breaks out nobly, and directs thine arm
To kill this base King?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No all the gods require it, they are dishonoured in him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You're valiant in his bed, and bold enough
To be a stale whore, and have your madam's name,
Discourse for grooms and pages, and hereafter
When his cool majesty hath laid you by
To be at pension with some needy sir
For meat and courser clothes, thus far you had no fear.
Come you shall kill him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And 'twere to kiss him dead, thou'dst smother him.
Be wise and kill him, canst thou live and know
What noble minds shall make thee see thyself,
Found out with every finger, made the shame
Of all successions, and in this thy ruin
Thy brother and thy noble husband broken?
Thou shalt not live thus, kneel and swear to help me
When I shall call thee to it, or by all
Holy in heaven and earth thou shalt not live
To breathe a foul hour longer, not a thought.
Come 'tis a righteous oath, give me thy hand,
And both to heaven held up, swear by that wealth
This lustful thief stole from thee, when I say it,
To let his foul soul out.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Here I swear it,
And all you spirits of abused ladies,
Help me in this performance.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Enough, this must be known to none
but you and I Euadne, not to your lord,
Though he be wise and noble, and a fellow
Dare step as far into a worthy action,
As the most daring, I as far as justice.
Ask me not why. Farewell. Exit Mel.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Would I could say so to my black disgrace,
Gods where have I been all this time; how friended,
That I should lose myself thus desperately,
And none for pity show me how I wandered.
There is not in the compass of the light
A more unhappy creature, sure I am monstrous,
For I have done those follies those mad mischiefs
Would dare a woman. O my loaden soul,
Be not so cruel to me, choke not upEnter Amintor.
The way to my repentance. O my lord.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I do not kneel to live, I dare not hope it,
The wrongs I did are greater, look upon me
Though I appear with all my faults.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Stand up.
This is a new way to beget more sorrows,
Heaven knows I have too many, do not mock me,
Though I am tame and bred up with my wrongs▪
Which are my foster-brothers, I may leap
Like a hand-wolf into my natural wildness,
And do an outrage, prithee do not mock me.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: My whole life is so leprous it infects
All my repentance, I would buy your pardon
Though at the highest set, even with my life,
That sleight contrition, that; no sacrifice
For what I have committed.

sp.speaker: Amint
sp.l: Sure I dazzle.
There cannot be a faith in that foul woman
That knows no god more mighty than her mischiefs,
Thou dost still worse, still number on thy faults,
to press my poor heart thus. Can I believe
There's any seed of virtue in that woman
Left to shoot up, that dares go in sin
Known and so known as thine is, oh Euadne,
Would there were any safety in thy sex,
That I might put a thousand sorrows off,
And credit thy repentance, but I must not,
Thou hast brought me to that dull calamity,
To that strange misbelief of all the world,
And all things that are in it, that I fear
I shall fall like a tree, and find my grave,
Only remembering that I grieve.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: My lord,
Give me your griefs, you are an innocent,
A soul as white as heaven, let not my sins
Perish your noble youth, I do not fall here
To shadow by dissembling with my tears
As all say women can, or to make less
What my hot will hath done, which heaven and you
Knows to be tougher than the hand of time
Shall cut from man's remembrance, no I do not,
I do appear the same, the same Euadne,
Dressed in the shames I lived in, the same monster.
But these are names of honour to what I am,
I do present myself the foulest creature,
