Most poisonous, dangerous, and despised of men
Lerna ere bred or Nilus, I am hell,
Till you my dear lord shoot your light into me,
The beams of your forgiveness, I am soul sick,
And wither with the fear of one condemned,
Till I have got your pardon.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Rise Euadne.
Those heavenly powers that put this good into thee
Grant a continuance of it, I forgive thee
Make thyself worthy of it, and take heed
Take heed Euadne this be serious
Mock not the powers above that can, and dare
give thee a great example of their justice
To all ensuing eyes, if thou play'st
With thy repentance, the best sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I have done nothing good to get belief,
My life hath been so faithless, all the creatures
Made for heaven's honours have their ends, and good ones
All but the cozening crocodiles false women.
They reign here like those plagues, those killing sores
Men pray against, and when they die; like tales
Ill told, and unbelieved they pass away,
And go to dust forgotten: but my lord
Those short days I shall number to my rest,
(As many must not see me,) shall though too late,
Though in my evening, yet perceive a will
Since I can do no good because a woman,
Reach constantly at something that is near it,
I will redeem one minute of my age,
Or like another Niobe I'll weepe
Till I am water.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I am dissolved.
My frozen soul melts, may each sin thou hast,
Find a new mercy, rise, I am at peace:
Hadst thou been thus, thus excellently good
Before that devil King tempted thy frailty
Sure thou hadst made a star, give me thy hand
From this time I will know thee, and as far
As honour gives me leave, be thy Amintor,
When we meet next I will salute thee fairly,
And pray the gods to give thee happy days,
My charity shall go along with thee
Though my embraces must be far from thee,
I should ha' killed thee, but this sweet repentance
Locks up my vengeance, for which, thus I kiss thee
The last kiss we must take, and would to heaven
The holy priest that gave our hands together,
Had given us equal virtues, go Euadne
The gods thus part our bodies, have a care
my honour falls no further, I am well then.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: All the dear joys here, and above hereafter
Crown thy fair soul, thus I take leave my lord,
And never shall you see the foul Euadne
Till she have tried all honoured means that may
Set her in rest, and wash her stains away. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I cannot tell how I should credit this
From you that are his enemy.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: I am sure he said it to me, and I'll justify it
What way he dares oppose, but with my sword.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But did he break without all circumstance
To you his foe, that he would have the fort
To kill me, and then scape.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: If he deny it, I'll make him blush.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I so does every thing I say of late.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Yes I should sit
Mute whilst a rogue with strong arms cuts your throat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well I will try him, and if this be true
I'll pawn my life I'll find it, if't be false
And that you clothe your hate in such a lie
You shall hereafter dote, in your own house,
Not in the court.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Why if it be a lie
Mine ears are false, for I be sworn I heard it,
Old men are good for nothing, you were best
Put me to death for hearing, and free him
For meaning it, you would a trusted me
Once, but the time is altered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And will still where I may do with justice to the world, you have no witness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No more I mean there were that heard it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: How no more? would you have more? why am not
I enough to hang a thousand rogues.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But so you may hang honest men too if you please.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I may, 'tis like I will do so, there are a hundred will swear it for a need too, if I say it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: And 'tis hard if my word cannot hang a boisterous knave.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.l: SirEnter Strat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why where's all the company? call Amintor in
Euadne, where's my brother, and Melantius,
Bid him come too, and Diphilus, call allExit Strat.
That are without there, if he should desire
The combat of you, 'tis not in the power
Of all our laws to hinder it, unless
We mean to quit 'em.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Why if you do think
'Tis fit an old man, and a counsellor
To fight for what he says, than you may grant it.

div.stage: Enter Amintor, Euadne, Melant. Diph. lysippus. Cle. Stra.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come sirs, Amintor thou art yet a bridegroom,
And I will use thee so, thou shalt sit down,
Euadne sit, and you Amintor too
This banquet is for you sir, who has brought
A merry tale about him, to raise laughter
Amongst our wine, why Strato where art thou
Thou wilt chopped out with them unseasonably
When I desire 'em not.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p: 'Tis my ill luck sir, so to spend them then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Reach me a bowl of wine, Melantius thou art sad.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I should be sir the merriest here,
But I ha' ne'er a story of mine own
Worth telling at this time.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give me the wine.
Melantius I am now considering
How easy 'twere for any man we trust
To poison one of us in such a bowl.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I think it were not hard sir, for a knave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'faith 'twere easy, it becomes us well
To get plain dealing men about ourselves,
Such as you all are here, Amintor to thee
And to thy fair Euadne.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Have you thought of this Callianax.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Ye shall have it soundly I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Here my love,
This wine will do thee wrong, for it will set
Blushes upon thy cheeks, and till thou dost
A fault 'twere pity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet I wonder much
Of the strange desperation of these men
That dare attempt such acts here in our state,
He could not scape that did it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: It ought to be, if he got then away
He must wear all our lives upon his sword,
He need not fly the island, he must leave
No one alive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No I should think no man
Could kill me and scape clear but that old man.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: But I? heaven bless me, ay, should I my liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not think thou wouldst but yet thou mightst,
For thou hast in thy hands the means to scape,
By keeping of the fort, he has Melantius,
And he has kept it well.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: From cobwebs sir,
'Tis clean swept, I can find no other art
In keeping of it now, 'twas ne'er besieged
Since he commanded.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: I shall be sure of your good word,
But I have kept it safe from such as you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Keep your ill temper in,
I speak no malice, had my brother kept it
I should ha' said as much.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are not merry, brother drink wine,
Sit you all still, CallianaxAside
I cannot trust thus, I have thrown out words,
That would have fetched warm blood upon the cheeks
Of guilty men, and he is never moved,
He knows no such thing.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Impudence may scape, when feeble virtue is accused.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A must if he were guilty feel an alteration
At this our whisper, whilst we point at him,
You see he does not.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Let him hang himself,
What care I what he does, this he did say▪

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Melant. you can easily conceive
What I have meant, for men that are in faults
Can subtly apprehend when others aim
At what they do amiss, but I forgive
Freely before this man, heaven do so too;
I will not touch thee so much as with shame
Of telling it, let it be so no more.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I cannot tell
What 'tis you mean, but I am apt enough
Rudely to thrust into ignorant fault,
But let me know it, happily 'tis naught
But misconstruction, and where I am clear
I will not take forgiveness of the gods,
Much less of you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay if you stand so stiff, I shall call back my mercy.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I want smoothness
To thank a man for pardoning of a crime
I never knew.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not to instruct your knowledge, but to show you my ears are everywhere , you meant to kill me, and get the fort to scape.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, my bluntness will be pardoned, you preserve
A race of idle people here about you,
Facers, and talkers to defame the world
Of those that do things worthy, the man that uttered this
Had perished without food, be't who it will,
But for this arm that fenced him from the foe.
And if I thought you gave a faith to this,
The plainness of my nature would speak more,
Give me a pardon, for you ought to do't
To kill him that spoke this.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: I that will be the end of all,
Than I am fairly paid for all my care and service.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That old man, who calls my enemy, and of whom I
(Though I will never match my hate so low,)
Have no good thought, would yet I think excuse me,
And swear he thought me wronged in this.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Who I, thou shameless fellow that hast spoke to me
Of it thyself.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O then it came from him.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: From me, who should it come from but from me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Nay I believe your malice is enough,
But I ha' lost my anger, sir I hope
You are well satisfied.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Licip: cheer Amintor and his lady, there's no sound
Comes from you, I will come and do't myself.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: You have done all ready sir for me I thank you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Melantius I do credit this from him,
How sleight soe'er you make't.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: 'Tis strange 'a should believe an old man's word,
That never lied in's life.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I talk not to thee.
Shall the wild words of this distempered man;
Frantic with age and sorrow make a breach
Betwixt your majesty and me, 'twas wrong
To hearken to him, but to credit him
as much, at least, as I have power to bear.
But pardon me, whilst I speak only truth,
I may commend myself — I have bestowed
My careless blood with you, and should be loath
To think an action that would make me lose
That, and my thanks too: when I was a boy
I thrust myself into my country's cause,
And did a deed, that plucked five years from time
And styled me man then, and for you my King
Your subjects all have fed by virtue of my arm,
And you yourself have lived at home in ease,
So terrible I grew that without swords
My name hath fetched you conquest, and my heart
And limbs are still the same, my will as great
To do you service: let me not be paid
With such a strange distrust.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Melantius I held it great injustice to believe
Thine enemy, and did, if I did,
I do not, let that satisfy, what struck
With sadness all● more wine.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: A few fine words have overthrown my truth, a thou'rt a villain.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why, thou wert better let me have the fort,
Dotard, I will disgrace thee thus for ever,
There shall no credit lie upon thy words,
Think better and deliver it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: My liege, he's at me now again to do it, speak
Deny it if thou canst, examine him
Whilst he is hot, for if he cool again,
He will forswear it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is lunacy I hope, Melantius.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: He hath lost himself
Much since his daughter missed the happiness
My sister gained, and though he call me foe,
I pity him.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: A pity a pox upon you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Mark his disordered words, and at the mask

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Diagoras knows he raged, and railed at me,
And called a lady whore so innocent
She understood him not, but it becomes
Both you and me to forgive distraction,
Pardon him as I do.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I'll not speak for thee, for all thy cunning, if you will be safe chop off his head, for there was never known so impudent a rascal.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Some that love him get him to bed, why? pity should not let age make itself contemptible, we must be all old, have him away.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Callianax the King believes you, come, you shall go home, and rest, you ha' done well, you'll give it up when I have used you thus a month, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now, now, 'tis plain sir, he does move me still,
He says he knows I'll give him up the fort
When he has used me thus a month, I am mad
Am I not still?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I shall be mad indeed if you do thus,
Why should you trust a sturdy fellow there,
(That has no virtue in him, all's in his sword)
Before me; do but take his weapons from him
And he's an ass, and I am a very fool
Both with him, and without him, as you use me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Too well, call: but if you use
This once again I shall entreat some other
To see your offices be well discharged.
Be merry gentlemen it grows somewhat late,
Amintor thou wouldst be a-bed again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And you Euadne let me take thee in my arm, Melantius thou art as thou deservest to be, my friend,
Still, and for ever good call:
Sleep soundly, it will bring thee to thyself.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Manent Mel. and Cal.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Sleep soundly! I sleep soundly now I hope,
I could not be thus else. How dar'st thou stay
Alone with me, knowing how thou hast used me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You cannot blast me with your tongue, and that's the strongest
Part you have about ye.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Dost not thou look for some great punishment for this? I feel
Myself begin to forget all my hate,
And take't unkindly that mine enemy
Should use me so extremely scurvily.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I shall meet too, if you begin to take
Unkindness, I never meant you hurt.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Thou'lt anger me again; thou wretched rogue,
Meant me no wrong! disgrace me with the King,
Lose all my offices, this is no hurt
Is it, I prithee what dost thou call hurt?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: To poison men because they love me not,
To call the credit of men's wives in question,
To murder children, betwixt me and land,
This I call hurt.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: All this thou think'st is sport,
For mine is worse, but use thy will with me,
For betwixt grief and anger I could cry.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be wise then and be safe, thou mayst revenge.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I oth' the King, I would revenge of thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The short is, I will hold thee with the King
In this perplexity till peevishness
And his disgrace have laid thee in thy grave.
But if thou wilt deliver up the fort,
I'll take thy trembling body in my arms,
And bear thee over dangers, thou shalt hold
Thy wonted state.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: If I should tell the King, canst thou deny't again?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Nay then thou canst bring any thing about,
Melantius, thou shalt have the fort.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why well, here let our hate be buried, and
This hand shall right us both, give me thy aged breast
To compass.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Nay I do not love thee yet,
I cannot well endure to look on thee,
And if I thought it were a courtesy,
Thou shouldst not have it, but I am disgraced,
My offices are to be ta'en away,
And if I did but hold this fort a day,
I do believe the King would take it from me,
And give it thee, things are so strangely carried,
Ne'er thank me fort, but yet the King shall know
There was some such thing in't I told him of,
And that I was an honest man.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: He'll buy that knowledge very dear: Diph
What news with thee? Ent. Diphilus.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: This were a night indeed to do it in,
The King hath sent for her.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: She shall perform it then, go Diph
And take from this good man my worthy friend
The fort, he'll give it thee.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Art thou of the same breed? canst thou deny
This to the King too?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: With a confidence as great as his.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Touch not me, I hate the whole strain, if thou follow me a great way off, I'll give thee up the fort, and hang yourselves.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: He's finely wrought. Exeunt Call. Diph.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This is a night spite of astronomers
To do the deed in, I will wash the stain
That rests upon our house, off with his blood. Ent. Amint.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Melantius now assist me if thou beest
That which thou sayest, assist me, I have lost
All my distempers, and have found a rage
So pleasing, help me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Who can see him thus,
And not swear vengeance? what's the matter friend?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Out with thy sword, and hand in hand with me
Rush to the chamber of this hated King,
And sink him with the weight of all his sins
To hell for ever.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Twere a rash attempt,
Not to be done with safety, let your reason
Plot your revenge, and not your passion.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: If thou refusest me in these extremes,
Thou art no friend, he sent for her to me,
By heaven to me, myself, and I must tell ye
I love her as a stranger, there is worth
In that vild woman, worthy things Melantius,
And she repents, I'll do't myself alone,
Though I be slain, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: He'll overthrow my whole design with madness, Amintor.
Think what thou dost, I dare as much as valour,
But 'tis the King, the King, the King, Amintor,
With whom thou fightest, I know he's honest. Aside.
And this will work with him.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I cannot tell
What thou hast said, but thou hast charmed my sword
Out of my hand, and left me shaking here
Defenceless.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I will take it up for thee.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: What a wild beast is uncollected man!
The thing that we call honour bears us all
Headlong unto sin, and yet itself is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Alas how variable are thy thoughts?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Just like my fortunes, I was run to that,
I purposed to have chid thee for some plot
I did distrust thou hadst against the King
By that old fellow's carriage, but take heed,
There's not the least limb growing to a King
But carries thunder in't.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Why come then, and still remember we may not think revenge.

div.head: Actus 5.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Give me the key then, and sir let none be near.
'Tis the King's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I understand you madam, would 'twere mine,
I must not wish good rest unto your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis all I dare do madam, but the King will wake, and then methinks .

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: Saving your imagination, pray good night sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A good night be it then, and a long one madam, I am gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: The night grows horrible, and all about me
Like my black purpose, oh the conscienceK. a-bed .
Of a lost virtue, whither wilt thou pull me?
To what things dismal, as the depth of hell,
Wilt thou provoke me? Let no woman dare
From this hour be disloyal, if her heart
Be flesh; if she have blood and can fear, 'tis a madness
Above that desperate man's that left his peace,
And went to sea to fight, 'tis so many sins,
an age cannot repent 'em, and so great,
The gods want mercy for, yet I must through 'em,
I have begun a slaughter on my honour,
And I must end it there, 'a sleeps, o God,
Why give you peace to this untemperate beast,
That has so far transgressed you? I must kill him,
And I will do't bravely: the mere joy
Confirms me that I merit, yet I must not
Thus tamely do it as he sleeps, that were
To rake him to another world, my vengeance
Shall seize him waking, and then say before him
The number of his wrongs and punishments.
I'll shape his sins like furies till I waken
His evil angel, his sick conscience,
And then I strike him dead. King by your leave,Ties his arms to the bed.
I dare not trust your strength, your grace and I
Must grapple upon even terms no more.
So, if he rail me not from my resolution,
As I believe I shall not, I shall fit him.
My lord the King, my lord, 'a sleeps
As if he meant to wake no more, my lord,
Is he not dead already? Sir, my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My dear Euadne,
I have been dreaming of thee, come to bed.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: I am come at length sir, but how welcome?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What pretty new device is this Euadne?
What, do you tie me to you by my love?
This is a quaint one: come my dear and kiss me,
I'll be thy Mars, to bed my Queen of love,
Let us be caught together, that the gods may look,
And envy our embraces.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Stay sir, stay,
You are too hot, and I have brought you physic,
To temper your high veins.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prithee to bed then, let me take it warm,
here thou shalt know the state of my body better.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I know you have a surfeited foul body,
And you must bleed.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I you shall bleed, lie still, and if the devil
Your lust will give you leave, repent, this steel
Comes to redeem the honour that you stole
King, my fair name, which nothing but thy death
Can answer to the world.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I am not she, nor bear I in this breast
So much cold spirit to be called a woman,
I am a tiger, I am any thing
That knows not pity, stir not, if thou dost,
I'll take thee unprepared, thy fears upon thee,
That make thy sins look double, and so s●nd thee
(By my revenge I will) to look those torments
Prepared for such black souls.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou dost not mean this, 'tis impossible,
Thou art too sweet and gentle.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: No I am not,
I am as foul as thou art, and can number
As many such hells here: I was once fair▪
Once I was lovely, not a blowing rose
More chastely sweet, till thou, thou, thou foul canker,
(Stir not) didst poison me, I was a world of virtue,
Till your cursed court and you (Hell bless you for't)
With your temptations on temptations
Made me give up mine honour, for which (King)
I am come to kill thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art not.
I prithee speak not these things, thou art gentle,
And wert not meant thus rugged.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Peace and hear me.
Stir nothing but your tongue, and that for mercy,
to those above us, by whose lights I vow,
Those blessed fires, that shot to see our sin,
If thy hot soul had substance with thy blood,
I would kill that too, which being passed my steel,
My tongue shall reach: thou art a shameless villain,
A thing out of the overcharge of nature,
Sent like a thick cloud to disperse a plague
Upon weak catching women, such a tyrant,
That for his lust would sell away his subjects,
I all his heaven hereafter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hear Euadne,
Thou soul of sweetness, hear, I am thy King.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Thou art my shame, lie still, there's none about you
Within your cries, all promises of safety
Are but deluding dreams, thus, thus thou foul man,
Thus I begin my vengeance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold Euadne,
I do command thee, hold.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: I do not mean sir
To part so fairly with you, we must change
More of these love-tricks yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What bloody villainy
Provoked thee to this murder?

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Thou keptst me brave at court, and whored me, King,
Then married me to a young noble gentleman,
And whored me still.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Hell take me then, this for my lord Amintor,
This for my noble brother, and this stroke
For the most wronged of women. Kills him.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: Die all our faults together, I forgive thee. Exeunt.
Come now she's gone, let's enter, the King expects it, and will be angry.
'Tis a fine wench, we'll have a snap at her one of these nights as she goes from him.
Content: how quickly he had done with her, I see Kings can do no more that way then other mortal people.
How fast he is! I cannot hear him breathe.
Either the tapers give a feeble light, or he looks very pale.

sp.l: Let's look: alas, he's stiff, wounded and dead.
Treason.

sp.p: Run forth and call. Exit gent.

sp.l: This will be laid on us: who can believe
A woman could do this?
Fled, fled away, but there her woeful act
Lies still.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Farewell thou worthy man, there were two bonds
That tied our loves, a brother and a King,
The least of which might fetch a flood of tears:
But such the misery of greatness is,
They have no time to mourn, then pardon me.
Sirs, which way went she? Enter Strato.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.l: Never follow her,
For she alas was but the instrument.
News is now brought in that Melantius
Has got the fort, and stands upon the wall,
And with a loud voice calls to those few that pass
At this dead time of night, delivering
The innocence of this act.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I would I were not: follow all, for this must have a sudden stop. Exeunt.

div.stage: Ent. Melant. Diph. Calli on the walls.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If the dull people can believe I am armed,
Be constant Diph. now we have time,
Either to bring our banished honour's home,
Or to create new ones in our ends.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: I fear not,
My spirit lies not that way. Courage Callianax.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Would I had any, you should quickly know it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Speak to the people, thou art eloquent.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine eloquence to come to the gallows,
You were born to be my end, the devil take you,
Now must I hang for company, 'tis strange
I should be old, and neither wise, nor valiant.

div.stage: Enter lysippus. Diagoras. Cleon. Strato. Guard.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: See where he stands as boldly confident,
As if he had his full command about him.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.l: He looks as if he had the better cause, sir,
Under your gracious pardon let me speak it,
Though he be mighty spirited and forward
To all great things, to all things of that danger
Worse men shake at the telling of, yet certain
I do believe him noble, and this action
Rather pulled on then sought, his mind was ever
As worthy as his hand.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis my fear too,
Heaven forgive all: summon him lord Cleon.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Worthy Cleon welcome,
We could a wished you here lord, you are honest.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Well thou art as flattering a knave, though I dare not tell thee so. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I am sorry that we meet thus, our old love
Never required such distance, pray to heaven
you have not left yourself, and sought this safety
More out of fear then honour, you have lost
A noble master, which your faith, Melantius,
I'm sure might have preserved.

sp.speaker: Melant.
sp.l: Royal young man, those tears look lovely on thee,
Had they been shed for a deserving one,
They had been lasting monuments: thy brother,
Whilst he was good, I called him King, and served him,
With that strong faith, that most unwearied valour,
Pulled people from the farthest sun to seek him,
And beg his friendship, I was then his soldier,
But since his hot pride drew him to disgrace me,
And brand my noble actions with his lust,
(That never-cured dishonour of my sister,
Base stain of whore, and which is worse,
The joy to make it still so, like myself)
Thus I have flung him off with my allegiance,
And stand here mine own justice for revenge,
What I have suffered in him, and this old man
Wronged almost to lunacy.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Who I? You would draw me in, I have had no wrong,
I do disclaim ye all.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The short is this,
'Tis no ambition to lift up myself
Urgeth me thus, I do desire again
To be a subject, so I may be free;
If not, I know my strength, and will unbuild
This goodly town, be speedy, and be wise, in a reply.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.l: Be sudden sir to tie
All up again, what's done is passed recall,
And passed you to revenge, and there are thousands
That wait for such a troubled hour as this.
Throw him the blank.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Melantius, write in that thy choice,
My seal is at it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: It was our honours drew us to this act,
no gain, and we will only work our pardons.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: You disclaimed us all but now Callianax.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: That's all one,
I'll not be hanged hereafter by a trick,
I'll have it in.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You shall, you shall:
Come to the back gate, and we'll call the King,
And give you up the fort.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: This is my fatal hour, heaven may forgive
My rash attempt that causelessly hath laid
Griefs on me that will never let me rest,
And put a woman's heart into my breast,
It is more honour for you that I do,
For she that can endure the misery
That I have on me, and be patient too,
May live and laugh at all that you can do.
God save you sir. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: And you sir, what's your business?

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: With you sir now, to do me the fair office
To help me to your lord.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: I'll do him any service, but to haste,
For my affairs are earnest, I desire
To speak with him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir because you are in such haste, I would be loath to delay you longer: you cannot.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.p: It shall become you though to tell your lord.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir he will speak with nobody , but in particular, I have in charge about no weighty matters.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.p: This is most strange: art thou gold proof? there's for thee▪ help me to him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Pray be not angry sir, I'll do my best. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: How stubbornly this fellow answered me!
There is a vild dishonest trick in man,
more than in women: all the men I meet
Appear thus to me, are harsh and rude,
And have a subtlety in every thing,
Which love could never know; but we fond women
Harbour the easiest and the smoothest thoughts,
And think all shall go so, it is unjust
That men and women should be matched together.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Where is he? Enter Amintor and his man.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Please it your lordship to command your man
Out of the room, I shall deliver things
Worthy your hearing.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.p: O that that shape should bury falsehood in it. Aside.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: When you know me, my lord, you needs must guess
My business, and I am not hard to know.
For till the chance of war marked this smooth face
With these few blemishes, people would call me
My sister's picture, and her mine: in short,
I am the brother to the wronged Aspasia.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: The wronged Aspatia, would thou wert so too
Unto the wronged Amintor, let me kiss
That hand of thine in honour that I bear
Unto the wronged Aspasia, here I stand
That did it, would he could not, gentle youth
Leave me, for there is something in thy looks
That calls my sins in a most odious form
Into my mind, and I have grief enough
Without thy help.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: I would I could with credit.
Since I was twelve years old I had not seen
My sister till this hour, I now arrived,
She sent for me to see her marriage,
A woeful one, but they that are above
have ends in every thing, she used few words,
But yet enough to make me understand
The baseness of the injuries you did her,
That little training I have had, is war,
I may behave myself rudely in peace,
I would not though, I shall not need to tell you
I am but young, and would be loath to lose
Honour that is not easily gained again,
Fairly I mean to deal, the age is strict
For single combats, and we shall be stopped
If it be published, if you like your sword
Use it, if mine appear a better to you,
Change, for the ground is this, and this the time
To end our difference.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Charitable youth,
If thou beest such, think not I will maintain
So strange a wrong, and for thy sister's sake,
Know, that I could not think that desperate thing
I durst not do, yet to enjoy this world
I would not see her, for beholding thee,
I am I know not what, if I have ought
That may content thee, take it, and be gone,
For death is not so terrible as thou,
Thine eyes shoot guilt into me.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Thus she swore,
Thou wouldst behave thyself and give me words
That would fetch tears into my eyes, and so
Thou dost indeed, but yet she bade me watch,
Lest I were cozened, and be sure to fight
Ere I returned.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: That must not be with me,
For her I'll die directly, but against her
Will never hazard it.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.p: You must be urged, I do not deal uncivilly with those that dare to fight, but such a one as you
Must be used thus. She strikes him.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I prithee youth take heed,
thy sister is a thing to me so much
Above mine honour, that I can endure
All this, good gods — a blow I can endure,
But stay not, lest thou draw a timeless death
Upon thyself.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Thou art some prating fellow,
One that has studied out a trick to talk
And move soft hearted people; to be kickedShe kicks him aside.
Thus to be kicked — why should he be so slow
In giving me my death.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: A man can bear
No more and keep his flesh, forgive me then,
I would endure yet if I could, now show
The spirit thou pretendest, and understand
Thou hast no hour to live, what dost thou mean,They fight
Thou canst not fight, the blows thou mak'st at me
Are quite besides, and those I offer at thee
Thou spreadest thine arms, and takest upon thine breast
Alas defenseless.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: I have got enough,
And my desire, there is no place so fit
For me to die as here. Ent. Euadne.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Amintor I am loaden with events
That fly to make thee happy, I have joys
That in a moment can call back thy wrongs
And settle thee in thy free state again,
It is Euadne still that follows thee
But not her mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Thou canst not fool me to believe again,
But thou hast books and things so full of news
That I am stalled.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Noble Amintor put off thy amaze,
Let thine eyes loose, and speak, am I not fair,
Looks not Evad. beauteous with these rites now
Were those hours half so lovely in thine eyes
When our hands met before the holy man,
I was too foul within, to look fair then●
since I knew ill I was not free till now.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: There is presage of some important thing
About thee which it seems thy tongue hath lost,
Thy hands are bloody, and thou hast a knife.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: In this consists thy happiness and mine,
Joy to Amintor for the King is dead.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Those have most power to hurt us, that we love
We lay our sleeping lives within their arms,
Why thou hast raised up mischief to his height
And found one, to out-name thy other faults,
Thou hast no intermission of thy sins,
But all thy life is a continued ill,
Black is thy colour now, disease thy nature
Joy to Amintor, thou hast touched a life
The very name of which had power to chain
Up all my rage, and tame my wildest wrongs.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and since I could not find away
To meet thy love so clear, as through his life
I cannot now repent it.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Couldst thou procure the gods to speak to me,
To bid me love this woman, and forgive,
I think I should fall out with them, behold
Here lies a youth whose wounds bleed in my breast,
Sent by his violent fate to fetch his death
From my slow hand, this keeps night here
And throws an unknown wilderness about me.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Forgive me then and take me to thy bed,
We may not part.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Forbear be wise, and let my rage go this way.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.p: 'Tis you that I would stay, not it.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Take heed it will return with me.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: If it must be I shall not fear to meet it,
Take me home.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: For heaven's sake look more calm,
thine eyes are crueler, than thou canst make thy sword.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Away, away thy knees are more to me then violence,
I am worse than sick to see knees follow me,
For that I must not grant, for god's sake stand,

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I dare not stay, thy language,
In midst of all my anger, and my grief,
Thou dost awake some thing that troubles me,
And says I loved thee once, I dare not stay,
There is no end of woman's reasoning.Leaves her.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Amintor thou shalt love me now again,
Go I am calm, farewell, and peace for ever.
Euadne whom thou hat'st will die for thee. Kills herself.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I have a little humane nature yet
That's lest for thee, that bids me stay thy hand. Returns.

sp.speaker: Euad.
sp.l: Thy hand was welcome but it came too late,
O I am lost the heavy sleep makes haste.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: This earth of mine doth tremble, and I feel
A stark affrighted motion in my blood,
My soul grows weary of her house, and I
All over am a trouble to myself,
There is some hidden power in these dead things
That calls myself unto 'em, I am cold,
Be resolute, and bear 'em company,
There's something yet which I am loath to leave,
There's man enough in me to meet the fears
That death can bring, and yet would it were done,
I can find nothing in the whole discourse
Of death I durst not meet the boldest way,
Yet still betwixt the reason and the act
The wrong I to Aspasia did stands up,
I have not such another fault to answer,
Though she may justly arm herself with scorn
And hate of me, my soul will part less troubled,
When I have paid to her in tears my sorrow,
I will not leave this act unsatisfied,
If all that's left in me can answer it.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Was it a dream? There stands Amintor still,
Or I dream still.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: How dost thou? speak, receive my love and help:
Thy blood climbs up to his old place again,
There's hope of thy recovery.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.p: And talked of tears and sorrow unto her.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and till these happy signs in thee
Stayed my course, it was thither I was going.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Thou art there already, and these wounds are her●:
Those threats I brought with me, sought not revenge,
But came to fetch this blessing from thy hand.
I am Aspasia yet.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Dare my soul ever look abroad again?

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: ●i shall sure live Amintor, I am well,
A kind of healthful joy wanders within me.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: The world wants lines to excuse thy loss,
Come let me bear thee to some place of help.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Amintor thou must stay, I must rest here,
My strength begins to disobey my will.
How dost thou my best soul? I would fain live,
Now if I could, wouldst thou have loved me then?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Alas, all that I am's not worth a hair
From thee.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: Give me thine hand, mine eyes grow up and down,
And cannot find thee, I am wondrous sick.
Have I thy hand, Amintor?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Thou greatest blessing of the world, thou hast.

sp.speaker: Aspat.
sp.l: I do believe thee better than my sense,
O I must go, farewell.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: She sounds: Aspasia. Help, for god's sake: water,
Such as may chain life ever to this frame.
Aspasia, speak: what no help? yet I fool,
I'll chafe her temples, yet there nothing stirs.
Some hidden power tell her Amintor calls,
And let her answer me: Aspasia speak.
I have heard, if there be any life, but bow
The body thus, and it will show itself.
O she is gone, I will not leave her yet.
Since out of justice we must challenge nothing,
I'll call it mercy if you'll pity me,
You heavenly powers, and lend forth some few years
The blessed soul to this fair seat again.
No comfort comes, the gods defy me too.
I'll bow the body once again: Aspasia.
The soul is fled for ever, and I wrong
Myself, so long to lose her company.
Must I talk now? Here's to be with thee love,Kills himself.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: This is a great grace to my lord to have the new King come to him, I must tell him he is entering. O God, help, help.

div.stage: Enter lysippus. Melant. Call. Diph. Strat●.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.l: O there, there.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: These deaths are such acquainted things with me,
That yet my heart dissolves not. May I stand
Stiff here for ever: eyes call up your tears,
This is Amintor: heart, he was my friend,
Melt, now it flows, Amintor give a word
To call me to thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Melantius calls his friend Amintor, o thy arms
Are kinder to me than thy tongue,
Speak, speak.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That little word was worth all the sounds
That ever I shall hear again.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: O brother here lies your sister slain,
you lose yourself in sorrow there.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why dip. it is
A thing to laugh at in respect of this,
Here was my sister, father, brother, son,
All that I had, speak once again
What youth lies slain there by thee.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: 'Tis Aspasia,
My last is said, let me give up my soul
Into thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I never did repent the greatness of heart till now,
It will not burst at need.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: My daughter, dead here too, and you have all fine new tricks to grieve, but I ne'er knew any but direct crying.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I am a prattler, but no more.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: Fie how unmanly was this offer in you,
Does this become our strain.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: I know not what the matter is, but I am
Grown very kind, and am friends with you all now
You have given me that among you will kill me
Quickly, but I'll go home and live as long as I can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: His spirit is but poor, that can be kept.
From death for want of weapons,
Is not my hands a weapon sharp enough
To stop my breath, or if you tie down those,
I vow Amintor I will never eat
Or drink, or sleep, or have to do with that
That may preserve life, this I swear to keep.

sp.speaker: Lisip.
sp.l: Look to him though, and bear those bodies in
May this a fair example be ●● me.
To rule with temper, for on lustfull Kings
Unlooked for sudden deaths from God are sent,
But cursed is he that is their instrument.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
